title: 2 Samuel Chapter 24 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 24 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 24 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 24.

questions.question: Who moved David to number Israel and Judah?
options: The LORD
Joab
Gad
Araunah
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:1 states that the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and He moved David against them to number Israel and Judah.

questions.question: To whom did David give the command to number the people?
options: Joab
Gad
Araunah
Nathan
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:2 shows that David said to Joab the captain of the host to number the people.

questions.question: How many valiant men that drew the sword were in Israel according to Joab's report?
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:9 records that Joab gave the number of 800,000 valiant men in Israel.

questions.question: How long did Joab and his captains take to number the people?
options: Nine months and twenty days
One year
Six months
Three months
questions.correctAnswer: Nine months and twenty days
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:8 states that they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days after numbering the people.

questions.question: What did David do after he numbered the people?
options: Confessed his sin and asked the LORD to take away his iniquity
Celebrated with a feast
Went to war immediately
Built an altar
questions.correctAnswer: Confessed his sin and asked the LORD to take away his iniquity
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:10 tells that David's heart smote him and he confessed he sinned greatly and asked the LORD to take away his iniquity.

questions.question: Who was the prophet that received the word of the LORD regarding David's choice of punishment?
options: Gad
Nathan
Samuel
Eli
questions.correctAnswer: Gad
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:11 mentions that the word of the LORD came to Gad, David's seer.

questions.question: What three punishments did the LORD offer David to choose from?
options: Seven years of famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days' pestilence
Ten plagues, exile, or death
War, drought, or captivity
Loss of kingdom, blindness, or silence
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years of famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days' pestilence
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:13 states these three options were given to David by the prophet Gad.

questions.question: Which punishment did David choose to fall into the hand of?
options: The LORD
His enemies
The people
His servants
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:14 shows David chose to fall into the merciful hand of the LORD rather than men.

questions.question: How many men died from the pestilence sent by the LORD?
options: Seventy thousand
Fifty thousand
One hundred thousand
Ten thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:15 says that seventy thousand men died from Dan to Beersheba due to the pestilence.

questions.question: Where was the angel of the LORD standing when the plague was stopped?
options: Threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
City gate of Jerusalem
Mount Zion
Temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:16 states the angel of the LORD was by the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite when the plague was stopped.

questions.question: True or False: David asked the LORD to let the punishment fall on him and his father's house instead of the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:17 records David asking the LORD to let the hand be against him and his father's house, sparing the people.

questions.question: True or False: Araunah gave the threshingfloor and oxen to David as a gift without asking for payment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:23 states Araunah gave these things to David as a king would give to another king.

questions.question: True or False: David accepted Araunah's offer without paying for the threshingfloor and oxen.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:24 shows David insisted on buying the threshingfloor and oxen for fifty shekels of silver.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Samuel 24:21: 'To buy the threshingfloor of thee, to build an altar unto the LORD, that the ______ may be stayed from the people.'
options: plague
famine
peace
storm
questions.correctAnswer: plague
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:21 explains David's reason for buying the threshingfloor was to build an altar so that the plague might be stayed from the people.

questions.question: Where did David build an altar to the LORD?
options: Threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
Mount Moriah
City of Dan
Land of Beersheba
questions.correctAnswer: Threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:25 states David built an altar to the LORD at the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 24 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 24 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and self-reliance, wanting to prove their worth by their achievements. Based on 2 Samuel 24, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Rely on God's mercy rather than your own strength.
Trust in your own power to accomplish great things.
Ignore God's guidance and focus on numbers and success.
Avoid prayer and seek human advice first.
questions.correctAnswer: Rely on God's mercy rather than your own strength.
questions.explanation: David's numbering of Israel was against God's will and brought punishment, but David trusted in the LORD's mercy instead of human strength (2 Samuel 24:1-4, 14, 17).

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 24, what did David do after he realized he had sinned by numbering the people?
options: He confessed and prayed for God's forgiveness.
He ignored the sin and continued his plans.
He blamed Joab for the sin.
He sacrificed animals immediately without seeking God.
questions.correctAnswer: He confessed and prayed for God's forgiveness.
questions.explanation: David admitted his sin and asked God to take away his iniquity, demonstrating humility and repentance (2 Samuel 24:10, 17).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 24 teach us about trusting God's judgment in times of trial?
options: God’s mercies are great, so it is better to fall into His hands than man’s.
Avoid trusting God and seek human solutions first.
God is harsh and unforgiving in trials.
Trials should be ignored and not prayed about.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercies are great, so it is better to fall into His hands than man’s.
questions.explanation: David chose to trust God's mercy even in punishment, showing faith in God’s compassion during hardships (2 Samuel 24:13-14).

questions.question: What lesson about obedience and humility can we learn from David’s interaction with Araunah in 2 Samuel 24?
options: David insisted on paying for the threshingfloor and oxen, refusing to offer to God what cost him nothing.
David accepted Araunah’s gifts without payment.
David ignored Araunah and built the altar elsewhere.
David refused to build an altar and continued the plague.
questions.correctAnswer: David insisted on paying for the threshingfloor and oxen, refusing to offer to God what cost him nothing.
questions.explanation: David demonstrated integrity and reverence by paying full price for the altar site and sacrifices (2 Samuel 24:21-24).

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by the consequences of their mistakes. Based on 2 Samuel 24, what biblical encouragement would you share?
options: God allows consequences, but His mercy can restore and heal.
Mistakes lead to permanent rejection by God.
Ignore God and focus on self-reliance.
Punishment means God is angry forever.
questions.correctAnswer: God allows consequences, but His mercy can restore and heal.
questions.explanation: Though David’s sin brought a plague, God relented when David repented and offered sacrifices, showing God’s readiness to forgive (2 Samuel 24:15-17, 25).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 24 guide us in the practice of prayer and seeking God’s will?
options: David sought God’s will through the prophet Gad before making decisions.
David acted without consulting God.
Prayer was unnecessary for David’s decisions.
David relied on his own understanding only.
questions.correctAnswer: David sought God’s will through the prophet Gad before making decisions.
questions.explanation: David consulted Gad, the prophet, to receive God’s instructions and options, highlighting the importance of seeking God’s guidance (2 Samuel 24:11-13, 18).

questions.question: True or False: Joab was eager and fully supportive when David commanded him to number Israel and Judah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joab questioned the king’s desire to number the people and cautioned against it, showing concern for God’s will (2 Samuel 24:3).

questions.question: True or False: The plague stopped immediately when God saw David’s repentance and commanded the angel to stay his hand.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God commanded the angel to stop the destruction when David prayed and repented, showing God’s responsiveness to heartfelt repentance (2 Samuel 24:16-17).

questions.question: In 2 Samuel 24, what was the significance of David choosing to build an altar at the threshingfloor of Araunah?
options: It was the place where the angel stopped the plague, marking God’s mercy.
It was a random location with no meaning.
It was the site of a previous battle.
It was chosen by Joab, not David.
questions.correctAnswer: It was the place where the angel stopped the plague, marking God’s mercy.
questions.explanation: The altar was built where the angel stood, symbolizing God’s mercy and the end of judgment (2 Samuel 24:16, 18, 25).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 24 teach us about accountability and taking responsibility for our sins?
options: David accepted responsibility for his sin and asked God to punish him instead of the people.
David blamed others for his sin.
David ignored his sin and did not repent.
David justified his sin as right.
questions.correctAnswer: David accepted responsibility for his sin and asked God to punish him instead of the people.
questions.explanation: David acknowledged his sin and asked God to hold him accountable rather than innocent people (2 Samuel 24:17).

questions.question: What biblical principle about generosity and stewardship can be drawn from David's purchase of the threshingfloor in 2 Samuel 24?
options: Offerings to God should be given willingly and not be from what costs nothing.
It is acceptable to give God what is free without cost.
Generosity is optional and unrelated to worship.
Only kings need to give offerings.
questions.correctAnswer: Offerings to God should be given willingly and not be from what costs nothing.
questions.explanation: David insisted on paying for the land and oxen, teaching that true worship involves costly and sincere giving (2 Samuel 24:22-24).

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to rely on their own resources rather than God’s. Based on 2 Samuel 24, what advice would you give?
options: Trust in God’s mercy and guidance rather than your own understanding.
Rely solely on your own strength and resources.
Ignore God’s instructions if they seem inconvenient.
Count your resources and boast about them.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s mercy and guidance rather than your own understanding.
questions.explanation: David’s error was trusting in the number of his army instead of God, but he later trusted God’s mercy and guidance (2 Samuel 24:2-4, 14).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 24 illustrate the importance of humility in leadership?
options: David humbly repented and sought God’s forgiveness after his sin.
David arrogantly ignored God’s warnings.
David blamed others for the consequences.
David refused to admit his mistakes.
questions.correctAnswer: David humbly repented and sought God’s forgiveness after his sin.
questions.explanation: David’s humility is shown in his confession and prayer for forgiveness, even as king (2 Samuel 24:10, 17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After David's sin, the LORD offered him three choices through Gad: seven years of _______, three months of fleeing from enemies, or three days of pestilence.
options: famine
war
peace
prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: famine
questions.explanation: Gad told David the LORD offered him three choices, including seven years of famine (2 Samuel 24:13).

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 24 teach about the role of prophets in guiding believers?
options: Prophets convey God’s messages and instructions, as Gad did for David.
Prophets are irrelevant to decision-making.
Prophets only speak for themselves, not God.
Prophets should be ignored if their messages are hard.
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets convey God’s messages and instructions, as Gad did for David.
questions.explanation: Gad, David’s seer, brought God’s word and guidance to David, showing the prophetic role in spiritual leadership (2 Samuel 24:11-13, 18).

questions.question: What practical lesson about intercession and concern for others is shown in David’s prayer during the plague?
options: David asked God to have His hand against him and his family, not the people.
David ignored the suffering of the people.
David blamed the people for his sin.
David fled and avoided responsibility.
questions.correctAnswer: David asked God to have His hand against him and his family, not the people.
questions.explanation: David interceded on behalf of the people, showing a heart of love and responsibility (2 Samuel 24:17).

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 24 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 24.

questions.question: What was the initial cause of the event where David was moved to number Israel and Judah?
options: The anger of the LORD against Israel
A direct command from Joab
David's personal curiosity
A census requested by the elders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The anger of the LORD against Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:1 states that the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and He moved David to number them.

questions.question: In 2 Samuel 24, what was Joab's response to David's command to number the people?
options: He questioned why the king delighted in this thing
He immediately obeyed without question
He refused to carry out the order
He suggested numbering only Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why the king delighted in this thing
questions.explanation: Joab questioned David, asking why the king delighted in numbering the people, showing reluctance (2 Samuel 24:3).

questions.question: How long did the census of Israel take according to 2 Samuel 24?
options: Nine months and twenty days
Three months
One year
Six weeks
questions.correctAnswer: Nine months and twenty days
questions.explanation: Verse 8 reports the census took nine months and twenty days to complete.

questions.question: How many valiant men who drew the sword were counted in Israel during the census?
options: Eight hundred thousand
Five hundred thousand
One million
Seven hundred thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Eight hundred thousand
questions.explanation: Joab reported eight hundred thousand valiant men in Israel who drew the sword (2 Samuel 24:9).

questions.question: What was David's reaction after the census was completed?
options: He was struck with remorse and confessed his sin
He celebrated the military strength
He commanded a feast
He accused Joab of deceit
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck with remorse and confessed his sin
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:10 describes David's heart smiting him and his confession of having sinned greatly.

questions.question: Which prophet received the LORD's word about the punishment options for David's sin?
options: Gad
Nathan
Samuel
Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: Gad
questions.explanation: The LORD spoke to the prophet Gad, David's seer, regarding the punishment choices (2 Samuel 24:11).

questions.question: What were the three punishment options Gad presented to David?
options: Seven years famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days pestilence
Ten years war, exile, or death
Seven days storm, three years drought, or ten days plague
Captivity, loss of throne, or blindness
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days pestilence
questions.explanation: Gad gave David three options for punishment as detailed in 2 Samuel 24:13.

questions.question: Which punishment did David choose, and what was his reason?
options: To fall into the hand of the LORD because His mercies are great
To flee before his enemies for three months to avoid suffering
To endure seven years of famine to purify the land
To suffer three days of pestilence to test Israel's faith
questions.correctAnswer: To fall into the hand of the LORD because His mercies are great
questions.explanation: David chose to fall into the hand of the LORD, trusting in His mercy (2 Samuel 24:14).

questions.question: How many men died from the pestilence sent upon Israel?
options: Seventy thousand
Fifty thousand
One hundred thousand
Thirty thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: Verse 15 reports that seventy thousand men died from Dan to Beersheba due to the pestilence.

questions.question: Where was the angel of the LORD when the plague was stopped?
options: By the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
On Mount Zion
At the gates of Jerusalem
In the Valley of Jehoshaphat
questions.correctAnswer: By the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:16 states the angel was by the threshingfloor of Araunah when the LORD stopped the plague.

questions.question: What did David request when he saw the angel striking the people?
options: That the LORD's hand be against him and his father's house instead
That the angel continue the punishment
That the people be forgiven without sacrifice
That Joab be held responsible
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD's hand be against him and his father's house instead
questions.explanation: David prayed that the punishment fall on him and his family, sparing the people (2 Samuel 24:17).

questions.question: What did Gad instruct David to do following the plague?
options: Build an altar to the LORD on the threshingfloor of Araunah
Gather the people for public fasting
Lead a military campaign against the enemies
Announce a new census
questions.correctAnswer: Build an altar to the LORD on the threshingfloor of Araunah
questions.explanation: Gad told David to build an altar on Araunah’s threshingfloor (2 Samuel 24:18).

questions.question: How did Araunah respond when David came to buy the threshingfloor?
options: He offered it for free along with oxen and threshing instruments
He demanded a high price
He refused to sell the land
He requested David to build the altar elsewhere
questions.correctAnswer: He offered it for free along with oxen and threshing instruments
questions.explanation: Araunah gave all items to David without charge (2 Samuel 24:22-23).

questions.question: Why did David insist on buying the threshingfloor instead of accepting it as a gift?
options: He would not offer burnt offerings to the LORD that cost him nothing
He wanted to show his wealth
To prevent Araunah from gaining favor
To avoid appearing weak before the people
questions.correctAnswer: He would not offer burnt offerings to the LORD that cost him nothing
questions.explanation: David declared his intention to pay for the land, emphasizing the costliness of true worship (2 Samuel 24:24).

questions.question: What was the outcome after David built the altar and offered burnt offerings?
options: The LORD was intreated and the plague was stayed from Israel
The people continued to suffer famine
The enemy nations attacked Israel
The LORD was silent
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was intreated and the plague was stayed from Israel
questions.explanation: David’s offerings appeased the LORD, stopping the plague (2 Samuel 24:25).

questions.question: True or False: Joab and the captains of the host willingly and joyfully followed David’s command to number the people without any objection.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joab questioned the king’s desire to number the people, indicating reluctance (2 Samuel 24:3).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 24 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 24 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason God moved David to number Israel and Judah?
options: Because the LORD's anger was kindled against Israel
To prepare for war against neighboring nations
To collect taxes from the people
To organize a census for religious purposes
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD's anger was kindled against Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:1 states that the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and He moved David to number Israel and Judah. This reflects God's sovereign judgment on Israel's sin. This theme of divine discipline for sin is consistent with passages like 2 Chronicles 21:6, Psalm 78:34, and Hebrews 12:6, which show God's righteous anger and corrective discipline toward His people.

questions.question: How did Joab respond to David's command to number the people?
options: He warned the king it was a foolish thing
He eagerly obeyed without question
He refused to carry out the command
He suggested numbering only Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He warned the king it was a foolish thing
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 24:3, Joab questioned David's desire to number the people, calling it a foolish thing, indicating a recognition that such an act could be offensive to God. This aligns with wisdom literature warnings about pride (Proverbs 16:18), the danger of relying on numbers rather than God (Psalm 33:12-17), and the importance of fearing God over trusting in human strength (Jeremiah 17:5).

questions.question: How long did it take Joab and the captains to complete the census of Israel?
options: Nine months and twenty days
Three months and ten days
One year
Six months
questions.correctAnswer: Nine months and twenty days
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 24:8, the census took nine months and twenty days to complete, indicating a thorough and extensive process. The length emphasizes the seriousness of the task and contrasts with God's perspective on human counting and reliance on self rather than divine provision (Exodus 30:12, Numbers 1:2-3).

questions.question: What was David's immediate reaction after the census was completed?
options: He acknowledged his sin and asked God to remove his iniquity
He celebrated the great number of soldiers
He ordered a sacrifice immediately
He consulted his generals about the next battle
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledged his sin and asked God to remove his iniquity
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 24:10, David's heart smote him, and he confessed his great sin before the LORD, pleading for forgiveness. This shows his repentance and recognition that numbering the people was an offense against God. This attitude resonates with biblical calls to repentance (Psalm 51:3-4, Isaiah 55:7, 1 John 1:9, and Luke 18:13).

questions.question: What three punishments did God offer David through the prophet Gad?
options: Seven years of famine, three months of fleeing from enemies, or three days of pestilence
Ten plagues, exile, or loss of the throne
Three years of drought, seven years of war, or three days of blindness
A lifetime of sorrow, loss of family, or abandonment by God
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years of famine, three months of fleeing from enemies, or three days of pestilence
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:13 records that Gad presented David with three options for punishment: seven years of famine, three months fleeing from enemies, or three days of pestilence. This demonstrates God's sovereign right to discipline with various judgments, consistent with Old Testament examples like Exodus 32:35 or the plagues in Numbers 16:46-50, and New Testament affirmations of God's justice (Romans 1:18, Revelation 6:8).

questions.question: Which punishment did David choose and why?
options: He chose to fall into the hand of the LORD, because His mercies are great
He chose the seven years of famine, to test Israel's endurance
He chose to flee before his enemies, to save the people
He chose the three days of pestilence, to end the judgment quickly
questions.correctAnswer: He chose to fall into the hand of the LORD, because His mercies are great
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:14 reveals David's choice to entrust himself to God's mercy rather than the hand of man, emphasizing God's attribute of mercy even in judgment. This reflects biblical theology of God's mercy triumphing over judgment (Exodus 34:6-7, Lamentations 3:22-23, Ephesians 2:4-5, James 2:13).

questions.question: How many men died as a result of the pestilence sent by the LORD?
options: Seventy thousand
One hundred thousand
Fifty thousand
Twenty thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:15 states that seventy thousand men died from Dan to Beersheba due to the pestilence. This shows the severity of divine judgment while also demonstrating God's control over life and death, consistent with passages such as 2 Kings 19:25, Jeremiah 15:2, Acts 5:1-11, and Romans 5:12.

questions.question: Where was the angel of the LORD when God stopped the destruction?
options: By the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
At the temple in Jerusalem
On Mount Zion
At the city gate of Beersheba
questions.correctAnswer: By the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:16 notes the angel was at the threshingfloor of Araunah when God told him to stop the destruction. This site later became significant for worship and sacrifice (2 Samuel 24:18-25), prefiguring God's provision of a place for atonement, consistent with typology seen in Genesis 22:13, Hebrews 9:11-14, and Isaiah 53.

questions.question: What did David request from God regarding the punishment on the people?
options: Let the punishment fall on him and his father's house instead
Let the punishment continue until Israel repents
Let the punishment be doubled on the people
Let the punishment be postponed for a year
questions.correctAnswer: Let the punishment fall on him and his father's house instead
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:17 shows David asking God to spare the people and instead allow the judgment to fall on himself and his family, showing his role as a mediator. This foreshadows the mediatorial role of Christ (Isaiah 53:4-6, 1 Timothy 2:5, Hebrews 7:25, Romans 8:34).

questions.question: What instruction did Gad give to David concerning the punishment?
options: Go up and build an altar to the LORD at the threshingfloor of Araunah
Lead the people in fasting and prayer for seven days
Offer a burnt offering in the temple
Send a delegation to ask for forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: Go up and build an altar to the LORD at the threshingfloor of Araunah
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:18 records Gad's instruction for David to build an altar on the threshingfloor, highlighting the importance of sacrifice and atonement in restoring fellowship with God. This aligns with the sacrificial system (Leviticus 1:3-4), the prophetic call to repentance and worship (Joel 2:13), and the ultimate sacrifice of Christ (Hebrews 10:10-14).

questions.question: How did Araunah respond when David came to buy the threshingfloor?
options: He offered it to David for free along with oxen and threshing instruments
He refused to sell it, saying it was holy ground
He demanded a high price for the land
He asked David to bring a priest first
questions.correctAnswer: He offered it to David for free along with oxen and threshing instruments
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:22-23 shows Araunah offering the land and materials to David for free, demonstrating generosity and humility. David, however, insisted on paying, emphasizing the principle that true worship requires personal cost (2 Samuel 24:24). This teaches that grace requires sacrifice (Mark 12:41-44, Romans 12:1).

questions.question: Why did David insist on buying the threshingfloor rather than accepting it for free?
options: He wanted to offer sacrifices that cost him something
He did not trust the land's owner
He planned to build a palace there
He wanted to keep it as a private property
questions.correctAnswer: He wanted to offer sacrifices that cost him something
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:24 reveals David's conviction that sacrifices to God must come at a personal cost, reflecting sincere worship rather than superficial offerings. This principle is consistent with the Old Testament sacrificial system (Leviticus 22:18-25), teachings on giving (2 Corinthians 9:7), and Christ's call for wholehearted devotion (Matthew 22:37).

questions.question: What was the result after David built the altar and offered sacrifices?
options: The LORD was intreated and the plague was stayed from Israel
The people rebelled against David
The pestilence increased in severity
David was crowned king over the entire land
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was intreated and the plague was stayed from Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:25 records that after the sacrifices, God was appeased and stopped the plague, illustrating God's readiness to forgive and restore when His people repent and offer proper worship. This is consistent with the covenantal themes in Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 103:8-13, and 2 Chronicles 7:14.

questions.question: What theological truth about God's character is revealed by His repentance from sending the angel to destroy Jerusalem?
options: God is merciful and can relent from judgment
God changes His mind like humans do
God is unpredictable and inconsistent
God is powerless to complete His judgments
questions.correctAnswer: God is merciful and can relent from judgment
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 24:16 shows God stopping the angel from destroying Jerusalem, demonstrating divine mercy and the ability to relent. While God's repentance is anthropomorphic, it reveals His compassion and justice, consistent with Jonah 3:10, Exodus 32:14, and the New Testament portrayal of God's steadfast love (1 John 4:8, Romans 9:15).

questions.question: How does David’s act of confession and intercession in this chapter prefigure Christ’s mediatorial role?
options: David takes the punishment upon himself for the people, similar to Christ as mediator
David builds a temple like Christ would later do
David leads the people in war as Christ leads spiritually
David writes psalms like Christ is the Word
questions.correctAnswer: David takes the punishment upon himself for the people, similar to Christ as mediator
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 24:17, David asks God to let the punishment fall on him and his family rather than the people, a foreshadowing of Christ’s atoning sacrifice as mediator who bears the sins of His people (Isaiah 53:4-6, 1 Timothy 2:5, Hebrews 7:25, Romans 8:34).

questions.question: What does the episode of numbering Israel teach about human sin and reliance on self?
options: Counting the people reflected pride and distrust in God's provision
Numbering was a neutral act without spiritual consequence
It was a required act to prepare for war
It demonstrated obedience to God’s command
questions.correctAnswer: Counting the people reflected pride and distrust in God's provision
questions.explanation: The census undertaken by David, despite Joab's warnings, reveals human pride and reliance on military strength rather than God’s sovereignty (2 Samuel 24:1-10). This theme is echoed in Numbers 1:1-3, Psalm 33:12-17, and Jeremiah 17:5, emphasizing that trust should be placed in God rather than human numbers.
